mods:mods.mods:abstract: Has received his letter with copies of the report on Indian Affairs, the constitution of "a new Society for the Benefit of Indians," the resolution of the American Board of Commissioners for foreign missions, and the prospectus of "The New York Observer." As he indicated in his letter of 10 June, to communicate fully his views on Indians and our duties toward them is beyond his capacity in his present state of health. The progress of the society will probably be languid unless government and public opinion should give it support. Mrs. Banyer is a subscriber to the New York Observer. Morse's son should have no reason to regret settling in New York City if he allows out of his hands only those works which merit commendation. Regarding his request for aid in continuing Trumbull's History of the United States from 1765 to 1792, would like to know first how much of his correspondence will be published by Congress as lately directed. His opinion of Morse's "General American Geography" renders him desirous that the proposed work be facilitated and will induce him to communicate any material documents in his possession where it would not be improper.
